text-center","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"text-base md:text-sm text-muted-foreground mb-1","children":"Cathedral"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-base md:text-sm","children":"Largest church in Argentina"}]]}]}]]}]}]}]
24:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":["About Living in ","La Plata"]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground leading-relaxed text-lg","children":"La Plata is Argentina's most fascinating urban experiment — a city designed from scratch in 1882 with a perfect diagonal grid, a park every six blocks, and a cathedral that took 115 years to complete (and was worth the wait). As the capital of Buenos Aires Province, it's an administrative center, but its real identity comes from the National University of La Plata (UNLP) — one of Argentina's top universities. The 100,000+ students create a vibrant, affordable, and cultured city that operates at a fraction of Buenos Aires' cost while being just 60 km away. The La Plata cathedral is genuinely stunning — a neo-Gothic masterpiece that rivals European cathedrals. The natural history museum is world-class. For expats, La Plata offers university-town charm, excellent architecture, and easy BA access at significantly lower prices."}]]}]}]}]
